prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We aim to observe continuum at 1.1mm. Therefore, we request TDM.

Given the size of massive compact quiescent/star-forming galaxies at z~2 (van del Wel et al 2014, Barro et al. 2013), the size of star-forming region in the compaction phase is expected to be Re~1kpc (diameter of ~0.2 arcsec). Therefore, we request observations with 0.2 arcsec angular resolution. If gas does not conentrate on the core with Re~1kpc, it could be as extended as stellar disks. As the stellar disk size for our targets is Re=2-6kpc (diameter of ~0.5-1.5 arcsec), we request the largest angular scale of 1.5 arcsec.

The stellar mass range of our targets is log(Mstar/Msun)=10.7-11.3. In the case of z~2 star-forming galaxies around the main-sequence, a gas fraction is Mgas/Mstar~1, which is anchored by CO observations (Tacconi et al. 2013) and the scaling relation by Genzel et al. (2015). Therefore, the expected gas mass is log(Mgas/Msun)>10.6 for most of our targets in this proposal even if taking into account a variation in gas fraction (0.24 dex; Genzel et al. 2015). Using a graybody radiation model with Tdust=25K (Magnelli et al. 2014, Genzel et al. 2015, Scoville et al. 2014), we find that log(Mgas/Msun)=10.6 corresponds to a 1.1 mm flux of 450uJy at z=2.2. If we assume Tdust=30, the corresponding 1.1 mm flux becomes larger.
As our goal is to identify a starburst core with Re=1kpc at z~2, 0.2 arcsec angular resolution is required (C32-5 configuration). Acconding to the CASA simulations in C32-5 (Figure 3 in Scientific Justification), we need to reach a sensitivity of 1sigma=40uJy to detect a compact submillimeter core (with Re=1kpc and S1.1mm(total)=450uJy) above 5sigma (per synthesized beam) in the re-constructed map.
Assuming graybody radtion with Td=25K, 1.1 mm fluxes increase by a factor of 1.5, compared to 1.3 mm fluxes. Therefore, we request observations at 1.1 mm in terms of integration time.
We aim to observe continuum at 1.1mm. Therefore, we request TDM.

As our goal is to measure total 1.1 mm fluxes from entire galaxies with Re=2-6kpc (0.5~1.5 arcsec) at z=2.0-2.6, we request the angular resoltuion of 1.5 arcsec (the largest beam at Band-6, C32-1 configuration) and the largest angular scale of 1.5 arcsec.

The stellar mass range of our targets is logMstar=10.7-11.3. In the case of z~2 star-forming galaxies around the main-sequence, a gas fraction is Mgas/Mstar~1, which is anchored by CO observations (Tacconi et al. 2013) and the scaling relation by Genzel et al. (2015). Therefore, the expected gas mass is logMgas>10.6 for our targets in this proposal. Using the stellar mass-metallicity relation at z~2 (Wuyts et al. 2014), the metallicity-dependent gas-dust ratio (Leroy et al. 2011), graybody radiation model with Tdust=25K (Magnelli et al. 2014, Genzel et al. 2015), we find that logMgas=10.6 corresponds to the 1.1 mm flux of 450uJy. To detect the continuum emission from entire galaxies above 5sigma, we need to reach a sensitivity of 1sigma=90uJy.
Assuming graybody radtion with Td=25K, 1.1 mm fluxes increase by a factor of 1.5, compared to 1.3 mm fluxes. Therefore, we request observations at 1.1 mm in terms of integration time.
We aim to observe continuum at 1.1mm. Therefore, we request TDM.

Given the size of massive compact quiescent/star-forming galaxies at z~2 (van del Wel et al 2014, Barro et al. 2013), the size of star-forming region in the compaction phase is expected to be Re~1kpc (diameter of ~0.2 arcsec). Therefore, we request observations with 0.2 arcsec angular resolution. If gas does not conentrate on the core with Re~1kpc, it could be as extended as stellar disks. As the stellar disk size for our targets is Re=2-6kpc (diameter of ~0.5-1.5 arcsec), we request the largest angular scale of 1.5 arcsec.

The stellar mass range of our targets is log(Mstar/Msun)=10.6-11.4. (2015). Therefore, the expected gas mass is log(Mgas/Msun)>10.6 for most of our targets in this proposal even if taking into account a variation in gas fraction (0.24 dex; Genzel et al. 2015). If we assume Tdust=30, the corresponding 1.1 mm flux becomes larger.
As our goal is to identify a starburst core with Re=1kpc at z~2, 0.2 arcsec angular resolution is required (C32-5 configuration). Acconding to the CASA simulations in C32-5 (Figure 3 in Scientific Justification), we need to reach a sensitivity of 1sigma=40uJy to detect a compact submillimeter core (with Re=1kpc and S1.1mm(total)=450uJy) above 5sigma (per synthesized beam) in the re-constructed map.

(2015). Therefore, the expected gas mass is log(Mgas/Msun)>10.6 for most of our targets in this proposal even if taking into account a variation in gas fraction (0.24 dex; Genzel et al. 2015). Using a graybody radiation model with Tdust=25K (Magnelli et al. 2014, Genzel et al. 2015, Scoville et al. 2014), we find that log(Mgas/Msun)=10.6 corresponds to a 1.1 mm flux of 450uJy at z=2.2. In the case of z~2 star-forming galaxies around the main-sequence, a gas fraction is Mgas/Mstar~1, which is anchored by CO observations (Tacconi et al. 2013) and the scaling relation by Genzel et al. (2015). Therefore, the expected gas mass is logMgas>10.6 for our targets in this proposal. Using the stellar mass-metallicity relation at z~2 (Wuyts et al. 2014), the metallicity-dependent gas-dust ratio (Leroy et al. 2011), graybody radiation model with Tdust=25K (Magnelli et al. 2014, Genzel et al. 2015), we find that logMgas=10.6 corresponds to the 1.1 mm flux of 450uJy. Assuming graybody radtion with Td=25K, 1.1 mm fluxes increase by a factor of 1.5, compared to 1.3 mm fluxes. Therefore, we request observations at 1.1 mm in terms of integration time.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Massive quiescent galaxies are extremely compact at z=2 while the majority of star-forming galaxies have more extended stellar disks. Theoretically, ~40% of massive star-forming galaxies are expected to form a dense compact core through dissipative processes such as violent disk instabilities or mergers (wet compaction).
We propose 1.1 mm observations of 20 massive log(M*)>10.6 rotation-dominated star-forming galaxies at z = 2.0-2.6, whose kinematic properties (including the spin parameter) and stellar structure are well-characterized by the KMOS3D/CANDELS/3D-HST surveys. High (0.2arcsec) and low (1.5arcsec) spatial resolution 1.1 mm mapping will allow us to characterize the true spatial distribution of the star formation activity and identify unambiguously the presence of compact (Re~1 kpc) starbursts in the galaxy centers.
By investigating whether the star-forming targets with low spin parameter more likely exhibit a central starburst compared to the mass- and star formation-matched control sample with high spin parameter, we will directly test the hypothesis that wet compaction plays a crucial role in bulge formation at the peak epoch of galaxy formation.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Racah Institute of Physics, The Hebrew University of Jerusalem
Division of Optical and Infrared Astronomy, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
Faculty of Exact Sciences , Tel Aviv University
